message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Epistasis and Adaptation on Fitness Landscapes
Paper Abstract: Epistasis occurs when the effect of a mutation depends on its carrier's genetic background. Despite increasing evidence that epistasis for fitness is common, its role during evolution is contentious. Fitness landscapes, which are mappings of genotype or phenotype to fitness, capture the full extent and complexity of epistasis. Fitness landscape theory has shown how epistasis affects the course and the outcome of evolution. Moreover, by measuring the competitive fitness of sets of tens to thousands of connected genotypes, empirical fitness landscapes have shown that epistasis is frequent and depends on the fitness measure, the choice of mutations for the landscape, and the environment in which it was measured. In this article, I review fitness landscape theory and experiments and their implications for the role of epistasis in adaptation. I discuss theoretical expectations in the light of empirical fitness landscapes and highlight open challenges and future directions toward integrating theory and data and incorporating ecological factors.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Mutation (genetic algorithm) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_(genetic_algorithm)"},{"title":"Mutation rate - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation_rate"},{"title":"Mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation"},{"title":"De novo mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/De_novo_mutation"},{"title":"Deletion (genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deletion_(genetics)"},{"title":"Suppressor mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Suppressor_mutation"},{"title":"Transition (genetics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transition_(genetics)"},{"title":"Polar mutation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Polar_mutation"},{"title":"Carney triad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carney_triad"},{"title":"Genetics of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics_of_amyotrophic_lateral_sclerosis"}]

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about mutations in genetics:

## What is a Mutation?

In biology, a mutation is an alteration in the nucleic acid sequence of the genome of an organism, virus, or extrachromosomal DNA.(no content)Mutations result from errors during DNA or viral replication, mitosis, or meiosis or other types of damage to DNA (such as pyrimidine dimers caused by exposure to ultraviolet radiation), which then may undergo error-prone repair, cause an error during other forms of repair, or cause an error during replication.

## Effects of Mutations

Mutations may or may not produce detectable changes in the observable characteristics (phenotype) of an organism.(no content)Mutations in genes can have no effect, alter the product of a gene, or prevent the gene from functioning properly or completely.

## Types of Mutations

Some major types include:

- **Point Mutations**: Point mutations are a class of mutations that are changes to a single base. Missense, nonsense, and synonymous mutations are three subtypes of point mutations.

- **Transitions**: Transition refers to a point mutation that changes a purine nucleotide to another purine (A ↔ G), or a pyrimidine nucleotide to another pyrimidine (C ↔ T).

- **Deletions**: In genetics, a deletion is a mutation in which a part of a chromosome or a sequence of DNA is left out during DNA replication.

## Evolutionary Importance

Mutation is the ultimate source of all genetic variation, providing the raw material on which evolutionary forces such as natural selection can act.(no content)Mutations play a part in both normal and abnormal biological processes including: evolution, cancer, and the development of the immune system.

Links: [{"title":"Background selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Background_selection"},{"title":"Genomic selection - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genomic_selection"},{"title":"Shapiro syndrome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shapiro_syndrome"},{"title":"WIN 55,212-2 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WIN_55,212-2"},{"title":"Rudolph Leibel - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rudolph_Leibel"},{"title":"Race and genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_and_genetics"},{"title":"Genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetics"},{"title":"Genetic Studies of Genius - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genetic_Studies_of_Genius"},{"title":"Rendille people - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rendille_people"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about genetic background:

## Definition and Significance

The genetic background, or genomic environment, of a mutation has a significant impact on whether it will be preserved versus lost from a population. In genetics, this term refers to the broader genomic context in which specific genetic variations exist.

## Scientific Applications

The concept of genetic background is important in various research areas:

1. **Population Genetics**: Background selection describes the loss of genetic diversity at a locus due to negative selection against deleterious alleles with which it is in linkage disequilibrium.

2. **Disease Research**: Genetic background can have an influence on the development of Shapiro syndrome. This illustrates how an individual's overall genetic makeup affects disease susceptibility and expression.

3. **Experimental Research**: WIN 55,212-2 reduces voluntary wheel running in laboratory mice, but with effects that depend on both genetic background and sex. This shows that genetic background affects how organisms respond to various stimuli.

## General Context

Genetic processes work in combination with an organism's environment and experiences to influence development and behavior, often referred to as nature versus nurture. Understanding genetic background is crucial for comprehending how inherited traits interact with environmental factors to shape an organism's characteristics and health outcomes.

Web search results for query: "Phenotype"

Links: [{"title":"Phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype"},{"title":"The Extended Phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Extended_Phenotype"},{"title":"Phenotype (album) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(album)"},{"title":"Phenotype (igneous petrology) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(igneous_petrology)"},{"title":"Human Phenotype Ontology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_Phenotype_Ontology"},{"title":"Phenotype microarray - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_microarray"},{"title":"Phenotype mixing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_mixing"},{"title":"Phenotype (clinical medicine) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype_(clinical_medicine)"},{"title":"Genotype–phenotype distinction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype–phenotype_distinction"},{"title":"Senescence-associated secretory phenotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senescence-associated_secretory_phenotype"}]

Here are the search results for "Phenotype":

## Main Definition

In genetics, the phenotype is the set of observable characteristics or traits of an organism.(no content)The term covers all traits of an organism other than its genome, however transitory: the organism's morphology (physical form and structure), its developmental processes, its biochemical and physiological properties whether reversible or irreversible, and all its behavior.

## How Phenotypes Develop

An organism's phenotype results from two basic factors: the expression of an organism's unique profile of genes (its genotype) and the influence of environmental factors experienced by that same organism which influence the variable expression of said genes, and thereby shape the resulting profile of defining traits.

## Genotype vs. Phenotype

The genotype–phenotype distinction is drawn in genetics. The "genotype" is an organism's full hereditary information. The "phenotype" is an organism's actual observed properties, such as morphology, development, or behavior.(no content)The terms "genotype" and "phenotype" were created by Wilhelm Johannsen in 1911.

## Behavioral Phenotypes

Behaviors and their consequences are also phenotypes, since behaviors are observable characteristics. Behavioral phenotypes include cognitive, personality, and behavioral patterns.

## Extended Phenotype

The book's main idea is that phenotype should not be limited to biological processes such as protein biosynthesis or tissue growth, but extended to include all effects that a gene has on its environment, inside or outside the body of the individual organism.

I've completed the web search for "Adaptation evolution biology." Here are the key findings:

## Overview of Adaptation in Evolution

Evolution is the change in the heritable characteristics of biological populations over successive generations, occurring when evolutionary processes such as genetic drift and natural selection act on genetic variation.

## Types of Adaptations

Adaptive traits may be structural (physical features like shape and body covering), behavioural (inherited systems of behaviour), or physiological (permitting organisms to perform special functions and maintain homeostasis).

## Natural Selection and Adaptation

While genotypes can slowly change by random genetic drift, natural selection remains the primary explanation for adaptive evolution.(no content)Adaptive evolution results from the propagation of advantageous mutations through positive selection.

## Related Evolutionary Concepts

- **Exaptation**: Exaptation is a shift in the function of a trait during evolution, where a trait can evolve because it served one function but subsequently come to serve another.

- **Co-adaptation**: Co-adaptation is the process by which two or more species, genes or phenotypic traits undergo adaptation as a pair or group.

- **Convergent Evolution**: Convergent evolution is the independent evolution of similar features in species of different lineages, creating analogous structures with similar form or function.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Genotype - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype"},{"title":"Genotype-first approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype-first_approach"},{"title":"Genotype frequency - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype_frequency"},{"title":"Four Core Genotypes mouse model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four_Core_Genotypes_mouse_model"},{"title":"HCV genotypes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/HCV_genotypes"},{"title":"Genotype–phenotype distinction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype–phenotype_distinction"},{"title":"Genotyping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotyping"},{"title":"Gene–environment interaction","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene–environment_interaction"},{"title":"Haplotype estimation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haplotype_estimation"},{"title":"ABO blood group system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/ABO_blood_group_system"}]

Here's what I found about genotype:

## Definition

The genotype of an organism is its complete set of genetic material.(no content)Genotype can also be used to refer to the alleles or variants an individual carries in a particular gene or genetic location.

## Key Characteristics

In diploid species like humans, two full sets of chromosomes are present, meaning each individual has two alleles for any given gene.(no content)If both alleles are the same, the genotype is referred to as homozygous. If the alleles are different, the genotype is referred to as heterozygous.

## Genotype vs. Phenotype

Genotype contributes to phenotype, the observable traits and characteristics in an individual or organism. However, the relationship isn't always straightforward. Not all individuals with the same genotype look or act the same way because appearance and behavior are modified by environmental and growing conditions.

## History

The term genotype was coined by the Danish botanist Wilhelm Johannsen in 1903.

## Practical Applications

Genotyping is the process of determining differences in the genetic make-up (genotype) of an individual by examining the individual's DNA sequence using biological assays and comparing it to another individual's sequence or a reference sequence.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Web search results for query: "Fitness landscape"

Links: [{"title":"Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"Evolutionary landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_landscape"},{"title":"Talk:Fitness landscape - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Fitness_landscape"},{"title":"File:DE Meta-Fitness Landscape (Sphere and Rosenbrock).JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:DE_Meta-Fitness_Landscape_(Sphere_and_Rosenbrock).JPG"},{"title":"File:PSO Meta-Fitness Landscape (12 benchmark problems).JPG - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:PSO_Meta-Fitness_Landscape_(12_benchmark_problems).JPG"},{"title":"NK model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/NK_model"},{"title":"Evolutionary algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutive_algorithm"},{"title":"Error threshold (evolution) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eigen's_paradox"}]

## Fitness Landscape

Here are the search results for "Fitness landscape":

### Definition and Core Concept

In evolutionary biology, fitness landscapes or adaptive landscapes (types of evolutionary landscapes) are used to visualize the relationship between genotypes and reproductive success.(no content)In all fitness landscapes, height represents and is a visual metaphor for fitness.

### Structure and Characteristics

Fitness landscapes are often conceived of as ranges of mountains. There exist local peaks (points from which all paths are downhill, i.e. to lower fitness) and valleys (regions from which many paths lead uphill).(no content)A fitness landscape with many local peaks surrounded by deep valleys is called rugged.(no content)An evolving population typically climbs uphill in the fitness landscape, by a series of small genetic changes, until – in the infinite time limit – a local optimum is reached.

### Applications Beyond Biology

Apart from the field of evolutionary biology, the concept of a fitness landscape has also gained importance in evolutionary optimization methods such as genetic algorithms or evolution strategies. In evolutionary optimization, one tries to solve real-world problems (e.g., engineering or logistics problems) by imitating the dynamics of biological evolution.

### Dynamic Fitness Landscapes

Fitness seascapes extend the static fitness-landscape model by allowing the adaptive topography to shift through time or across changing environments. Rather than a fixed topography, seascapes describe adaptive surfaces whose peaks and valleys change in time as selection pressures evolve.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Epistasis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis"},{"title":"Epistasis and functional genomics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis_and_functional_genomics"},{"title":"Talk:Epistasis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Epistasis"},{"title":"Hypostatic gene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypostatic_gene"},{"title":"Population genetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Population_geneticist"},{"title":"Interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interaction"},{"title":"POU4F1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/POU4F1"},{"title":"Talk:Supergene - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Supergene"}]

## Epistasis

Epistasis is a phenomenon in genetics in which the effect of a gene mutation is dependent on the presence or absence of mutations in one or more other genes, respectively termed modifier genes.(no content)In other words, the effect of the mutation is dependent on the genetic background in which it appears.

### Historical Background

The term was first used in 1907 by William Bateson and his collaborators Florence Durham and Muriel Wheldale Onslow.

### Types of Epistasis

In classical genetics, epistasis relationships are classified by how mutations interact:

- **Positive epistasis**: When the double mutation has a fitter phenotype than expected from the effects of the two single mutations, positive epistasis between beneficial mutations generates greater improvements in function than expected, while positive epistasis between deleterious mutations protects against the negative effects to cause a less severe fitness drop.

- **Negative epistasis**: When two mutations together lead to a less fit phenotype than expected from their effects when alone, it is called negative epistasis, where negative epistasis between beneficial mutations causes smaller than expected fitness improvements, whereas negative epistasis between deleterious mutations causes greater-than-additive fitness drops.

- **Synergistic epistasis**: When the effect on fitness of two mutations is more radical than expected from their effects when alone, it is referred to as synergistic epistasis.

### Relationship to Genetic Dominance

Epistasis can be contrasted with genetic dominance, which is an interaction between alleles at the same gene locus.

### Significance

Epistasis has a great influence on the shape of evolutionary landscapes, which leads to profound consequences for evolution and for the evolvability of phenotypic traits.

## Epistasis

Epistasis is a phenomenon in genetics in which the effect of a gene mutation is dependent on the presence or absence of mutations in one or more other genes, respectively termed modifier genes.(no content)In other words, the effect of the mutation is dependent on the genetic background in which it appears.

### Historical Background

The term was first used in 1907 by William Bateson and his collaborators Florence Durham and Muriel Wheldale Onslow.

### Types of Epistasis

In classical genetics, epistasis relationships are classified by how mutations interact:

- **Positive epistasis**: When the double mutation has a fitter phenotype than expected from the effects of the two single mutations, positive epistasis between beneficial mutations generates greater improvements in function than expected, while positive epistasis between deleterious mutations protects against the negative effects to cause a less severe fitness drop.

- **Negative epistasis**: When two mutations together lead to a less fit phenotype than expected from their effects when alone, it is called negative epistasis, where negative epistasis between beneficial mutations causes smaller than expected fitness improvements, whereas negative epistasis between deleterious mutations causes greater-than-additive fitness drops.

- **Synergistic epistasis**: When the effect on fitness of two mutations is more radical than expected from their effects when alone, it is referred to as synergistic epistasis.

### Relationship to Genetic Dominance

Epistasis can be contrasted with genetic dominance, which is an interaction between alleles at the same gene locus.

### Significance

Epistasis has a great influence on the shape of evolutionary landscapes, which leads to profound consequences for evolution and for the evolvability of phenotypic traits.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Evolution"

Links: [{"title":"Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution"},{"title":"Convergent evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Convergent_evolution"},{"title":"Differential evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Differential_evolution"},{"title":"Evolution (2015 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_(2015_film)"},{"title":"Human evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human_evolution"},{"title":"Mitsubishi Lancer Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mitsubishi_Lancer_Evolution"},{"title":"WWE Evolution (2025) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WWE_Evolution_(2025)"},{"title":"Evolution (2001 film) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution_(2001_film)"},{"title":"X-Men: Evolution - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/X-Men:_Evolution"},{"title":"GE Evolution Series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/GE_Evolution_Series"}]

Here are the search results for "Evolution":

## Biological Evolution

The modern evolutionary synthesis defines evolution as the change over time in genetic variation.(no content)Evolution can occur if there is genetic variation within a population.(no content)Variation comes from mutations in the genome, reshuffling of genes through sexual reproduction and migration between populations (gene flow).(no content)Evolution by natural selection is established by observable facts about living organisms: (1) more offspring are often produced than can possibly survive; (2) traits vary among individuals with respect to their morphology, physiology, and behaviour; (3) different traits confer different rates of survival and reproduction (differential fitness); and (4) traits can be passed from generation to generation. In successive generations, members of a population are therefore more likely to be replaced by the offspring of parents with favourable characteristics for that environment.(no content)Existing patterns of biodiversity have been shaped by repeated formations of new species (speciation), changes within species (anagenesis), and loss of species (extinction) throughout the evolutionary history of life on Earth.

## Human Evolution

Over their evolutionary history, humans gradually developed traits such as bipedalism, dexterity, and complex language.(no content)Modern humans interbred with archaic humans, indicating that their evolution was not linear but weblike.

The search results also include information about convergent evolution, differential evolution algorithms, and various entertainment properties named "Evolution."


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
Perfect! I have successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Epistasis and Adaptation on Fitness Landscapes." Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Summary

**Paper Type:** Survey

This paper is a comprehensive literature review of fitness landscape theory and its implications for understanding how epistasis affects evolution and adaptation.

**Extracted Entities (7 triples):**

1. **Epistasis** - A genetic concept describing how mutation effects depend on genetic background
2. **Fitness landscape** - The primary theoretical framework for mapping genotypes/phenotypes to fitness
3. **Adaptation** - The evolutionary process that the paper analyzes through the lens of fitness landscapes
4. **Mutation** - The fundamental unit of genetic change discussed in epistasis context
5. **Genotype** - One dimension of fitness landscapes (genotype-to-fitness mapping)
6. **Phenotype** - Another dimension of fitness landscapes (phenotype-to-fitness mapping)
7. **Evolution** - The broader biological process shaped by epistasis and fitness landscapes

All entities are classified as **concepts** since they represent abstract theoretical frameworks and biological principles rather than specific tools, methods, or datasets.

**Validation:** ✅ All checks passed successfully!

Sources:
- [Epistasis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Epistasis)
- [Fitness landscape](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fitness_landscape)
- [Adaptation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptation)
- [Mutation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mutation)
- [Genotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Genotype)
- [Phenotype](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Phenotype)
- [Evolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolution)
